dict.string: The human-readable name for the profile payload. The name appears on the Detail screen and doesn't need to be unique.

The reverse-DNS-style identifier for the payload. This identifier is usually the same as the TopLevel value, with an additional appended component. This string must be unique within the profile. During a profile replacement, the system updates payloads with the same 'PayloadIdentifier' and 'PayloadUUID' in the old and new profiles.
The payload type, which each payload domain's reference page specifies.

The globally unique identifier for the payload. The actual content is unimportant, but must be globally unique. In macOS, use 'uuidgen' to generate UUIDs. During a profile replacement, the system updates payloads with the same 'PayloadIdentifier' and 'PayloadUUID' in the old and new profiles.
The version of this specific payload.
The human-readable description of this payload. This description appears on the Detail screen.
Text shown in the top left corner when the app opens
Path to the logo shown in the top right corner when the app opens. Scales to 48 points maximum height

Some preference keys like the icon and status bar icon point to a file location. Due to the sandboxed characteristic of the app, not all file locations are allowed. We suggest putting the files in a folder within Application Support such as /Library/Application Support/Your Company/ where the app can read the contents. Other supported file locations can be found in Apple's documentation about App Sandbox: https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Security/Conceptual/AppSandboxDesignGuide/AppSandboxInDepth/AppSandboxInDepth.html#/apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40011183-CH3-SW17
Path to the logo shown in the top right corner when the app opens for Dark Mode. Scales to 48 points maximum height

Some preference keys like the icon and status bar icon point to a file location. Due to the sandboxed characteristic of the app, not all file locations are allowed. We suggest putting the files in a folder within Application Support such as /Library/Application Support/Your Company/ where the app can read the contents. Other supported file locations can be found in Apple's documentation about App Sandbox: https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Security/Conceptual/AppSandboxDesignGuide/AppSandboxInDepth/AppSandboxInDepth.html#/apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40011183-CH3-SW17

Some preference keys like the icon and status bar icon point to a file location. Due to the sandboxed characteristic of the app, not all file locations are allowed. We suggest putting the files in a folder within Application Support such as /Library/Application Support/Your Company/ where the app can read the contents. Other supported file locations can be found in Apple's documentation about App Sandbox: https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Security/Conceptual/AppSandboxDesignGuide/AppSandboxInDepth/AppSandboxInDepth.html#/apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40011183-CH3-SW17
Path to the status bar icon shown in the menu bar. Recommended: PNG, 16x16 points

Some preference keys like the icon and status bar icon point to a file location. Due to the sandboxed characteristic of the app, not all file locations are allowed. We suggest putting the files in a folder within Application Support such as /Library/Application Support/Your Company/ where the app can read the contents. Other supported file locations can be found in Apple's documentation about App Sandbox: https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Security/Conceptual/AppSandboxDesignGuide/AppSandboxInDepth/AppSandboxInDepth.html#/apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40011183-CH3-SW17
Custom status bar icon using an SF Symbol. Ignored when StatusBarIcon is also set
For more info on how to use SF Symbols, checkout https://github.com/root3nl/SupportApp/#how-to-use-sf-symbols
Custom Status Bar Icon using SF Symbols
Shows a small notification badge in the Status Bar Icon when there is an Apple Software Update available or when the UptimeDaysLimit or PasswordExpiryLimit is reached
Notification badge in Status Bar Icon
HEX color in RGB format. Example: #8cc63f. Leave empty to use macOS Accent Color
Root3 recommends to not to use a very light color as text may become hard to read.
HEX color in RGB format for Dark Mode. Example: #8cc63f. CustomColor is used when CustomColorDarkMode is not specified
Root3 recommends to not to use a very dark color as text may become hard to read.
Hides the first row of configurable items.
Hides the second row of configurable items.
Shown when clicking an action results in an error
A welcome screen and feature explanation to show when the app is first opened
Shown at the bottom as footnote. Supports both text and Emoji. Markdown is supported for macOS Monterey and higher

Disabled by default. Launch Support (non-PKG) automatically at login and keep it open (macOS 13 and higher). This setting is ignored if a legacy LaunchAgent is installed/active. Keep disabled if you don't want to open Support at login or use your own LaunchAgent
Info item shown in the upper left corner
Info item shown in the upper right corner
Info item shown in the second row left
Info item shown in the second row right
Info item shown in the third row left
Info item shown in the third row right
Days of uptime after which a notification badge is shown
Days until password expiry after which a notification badge is shown
Alternative text label shown in the Password info item
Percentage of storage after which a notification badge is shown
The text shown in the button label
Subtitle text will appear under title when the user hovers over the button. Ignored if left empty.
Type of link the item should open. Can be anything like screen sharing tools, company stores, file servers or core applications in your organization. App by default.

array.string: Command or Script (deprecated as of v2.6, use Privileged Script)

dict.string: The Bundle Identifier of the app, link, command or path to script

App: Bundle Identifier of the app URL: Link to a webpage or other links that would normaly work like PROTOCOL://URL Command: Zsh command or path to a script. Be aware that this will be executed as the user and therefore has its limitations

dict.string: The Bundle Identifier of the app, link, command or path to script.
Ignore macOS major updates. This will prevent the menu bar icon and the macOS version info item from showing an available major update.
The human-readable string containing the name of the organization that provides the profile. This value doesn't need to match the organization payload value in the enclosing dictionary.
Optional text to shown in the macOS Managed Updates popover to tell users about the updates
Hide the first row with Info Items
Hide the second row with Info Items
Hide the third row with Info Items
Hide the first row with configurable items
Hide the second row with configurable items
Password expiry information source: Apple (local account or AD), Jamf Connect or Kerberos SSO Extension
Path to script script or command to be executed when the Support App is opened by clicking on the menu bar item.
Option to enable or disable the Privileged Helper Tool. Re-enabling requires the reinstallation of the Support App.
Enable or Disable Privileged Helper Tool
